description:
Thogotovirus thogotoense is a species of virus belonging to the Orthomyxoviridae family. It is a segmented, negative-sense, single-stranded RNA virus that is primarily transmitted by ticks. The virus was first isolated from Rhipicephalus appendiculatus ticks collected in the Thogoto forest in Kenya.

Thogotovirus thogotoense has a genome consisting of six to eight RNA segments, which encode proteins essential for viral replication and assembly. The virus is capable of infecting a variety of vertebrate hosts, including humans, causing a disease known as Thogoto virus infection. Symptoms can range from mild febrile illness to more severe neurological complications.

The virus is classified within the Thogotovirus genus, which includes several other tick-borne orthomyxoviruses. Thogotovirus thogotoense is considered a zoonotic pathogen, as it can be transmitted from its natural tick reservoir to humans, posing a potential public health concern in areas where the virus is endemic.
